abstract.p: In this article, a study is reported on the ignition of timber board by an incandescent light. A set of experimental tests were conducted to demonstrate the possibility of such an event. Inference was then made to the possible cause of a fire incident that occurred at a building construction site a few years ago. Theoretical analysis was also conducted based on an ignition model. The model is able to correlate the time to ignition with the distance between the light bulb with a given power output and the timber board.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Understanding the causes of fires is a critical step for developing fire prevention strategies to safeguard life and properties. Statistically, electrical appliances contribute to a significant proportion of fire incidents. The case presented in section “Fire case and preliminary results of fire investigation” of this article is a typical example of the potential dangers of unprotected common incandescent light. Understanding ignition mechanism also helps fire investigations and resolves uncertainties related to causes of fires.

In response to the recommendation of a fire investigation report, a study has been conducted at the State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China to provide further supporting evidence that an incandescent light bulb was possibly the original cause of a fire that occurred at a construction site in Korla City, Sinkiang Autonomy Region in 2004.1 The study was based on experimental simulation of a number of possible ignition scenarios. Theoretical modeling was also applied to correlate the time of ignition to other control parameters.

sec.title: Fire case and preliminary results of fire investigation
sec.p: At 7 a.m. (the time when the fire was detected) on 16 March 2004, there was an extraordinary fire in the construction site of a complex building in Korla City, Sinkiang Autonomy Region.1 The building was a four-story office building as shown in Figure 1. The building was about 119 m from west to east, and the widest is 50.3 m from south to north. The building has an underground basement with a depth of 4.2 m and a total floor area of 4355 m2. The aboveground portion was composed of a modular building in the west and complex building containing Zones A and B. As shown in Figure 1, Zone A in the west of the complex building was three stories, 12.6 m in height, and 5649 m2 in building area; the other zone, Zone B, was a hotel, 21 m in height and 111,582 m2 in building area. There was an elevator room in the east of the building decorated by light steel keel fiber board stuck outside of the aluminum–plastic plate and its outside wall was toughened glass. The outside walls of two more floors were glass block screen wall of coating film in the south part of Zones A and B linking to each other.

caption.p: Computer-generated view of the building complex.

sec.p: The fire destroyed five elevators and a part of the indoor renovations, with a burnt area of more than 1000 m2. The eastern elevator room in Zone B was destroyed badly. The concrete phenomenon was described as follows: (a) five of the six elevators were destroyed, (b) some windows were burned down, (c) the decorations plugging the windows were also burned and had fallen off, and (d) the sills of the windows were distorted severely after the fire, a good amount of plaster of cement and wood charcoal appeared on the stairs, and the direct losses were about RMB (Ren Min Bi) 2.1 million. A field investigation was conducted to determine the cause of this extraordinarily huge fire accident.1 The location of the fire was identified between the east stairways on the third and fourth floors in Zone B, and the igniting point was located at the upper part of the iron armrests at the stairways in the northern building. By exclusion approach and proof of traces at the place of fire, a hypothesis was established that the fire ignition source was probably the incandescent bulbs in contact with the wood boards of the operation platform mounted at the upper part of the middle armrests in the northern building on the third and fourth floors as shown in Figure 2.1 To confirm the initial finding of the field investigation, an experimental study was conducted in the laboratory at State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China.

sec.title: Overview
sec.p: The ignition of timber board by a light bulb is a nonpiloted ignition process2 and is primarily controlled by external heat flux generated by the light bulb, which varies as a function of distance from the bulb as well as orientation relative to the bulb. The experimental study consisted of two sets of tests. The first set was a set of calibration tests in which the thermal radiation field around an incandescent light bulb was measured. The second set was a set of ignition simulation tests.

For ignition of solids, such as wood, the practical problem is usually the following: “For a given thermal attack, determine whether ignition will occur. If it does occur, determine how long it will take.” This immediately suggests the areas that must be quantified: (a) the thermal attack, (b) the heating up and pyrolysis of the solid, and (c) the association of the observation of flames with a quantifiable variable.

sec.title: Experimental apparatus and conditions
sec.p: The aim of the experimental apparatus design was to replicate what might have happened at the scene of the fire incident. Since the information about the location and orientation of the incandescent light bulb relative to the timber board in the Korla City fire incident was imprecise,1 several possible configurations were tested in the current investigation.

In the ignition simulation experiment, the timber board was placed horizontally. A bulb of incandescent lamp of the same model as that involved in the complex building fire incident was selected as the heating source against a piece of timber board. The power of the bulb was 200 W. Figure 3 depicts the experimental apparatus and the dimension of the incandescent light bulb. Thermocouple TC1 was placed along the axis of the bulb at the surface of the wood timber and thermocouple TC2 was placed at about 2 mm away from the surface of the wood timber.

In total, nine tests were conducted in the simulation experiment. The sample timber board orientation and the distance between the light bulb and the sample board were varied in these tests as summarized in Table 2.

sec.title: General observations of ignition simulation tests
sec.p: In Tests 1–6, the gap between the bulb and the timber board varied significantly as compared with tests in other orientations. Ignition was observed when the gap was less than 6 mm. In Test 1, where d = 0 mm, a circular carbonized zone of about 1 cm in diameter around the contact point with the bulb occurred on the board surface. Flaming ignition was visually seen in the region around the circle, though the measured surface temperature did not show a rapid increase at the time of ignition. It was likely that the flaming combustion occurred outside of the circle because of the lack of oxygen within. A layer of soot deposit was found on the surface of the bulb in this particular test.

In Tests 7 and 8, the sample boards could not be ignited in 3 h when d was either 3 or 0 mm. A circular slight carbonized zone also occurred on the board surface. Test 9, where the light bulb was placed above the timber board, was actually repeated a number of times. The outcome of these tests was quite unpredictable. In one of them, d = 3 mm, ignition was observed at about 1600 s. In others, no ignition was observed due to (a) deposition of soot on the surface of the bulb and (b) breaking or explosion of the bulb. The former may cause a reduction in direct thermal radiation flux to the fuel surface, and the latter interrupted the test all together. The explosion of the bulb was likely caused by the uneven heating of the light bulb surface and the pressure increase inside the bulb, which was attributed to immense temperature rise inside the bulb due to poor convection cooling of the bulb and the blockage of radiation heat transfer by the soot deposit.

sec.p: The ignition temperature, mass lose rate, and heat release rate (HRR) are widely applied as ignition criterion.2 In the current study, a thermocouple (TC1 showed in Figure 3) was located at the surface of the Paulownia wood board to determine whether ignition will occur. The sharp increase of temperature curve was characterized as the ignition occurred.

In Tests 2–6, the measured temperatures from thermocouple TC1 in various tests are shown in Figure 4. As the distance between the incandescent lamp and the Paulownia wood board increases, the time to ignition increases accordingly.

sec.p: On the temperature curve of the differential the time at the inflection point is recorded as the ignition time. The test conditions and results of the ignition simulation tests are summarized in Table 3.

The results in Tests 2–4 show that Tign decreases with increasing distance. In other words, Tign decreases with decreasing radiant heat flux. The ignition temperature measured is a bit higher than 523 K at low heat flux summarized by Babrauskas.2

It is seen from Table 3 that the time to ignition increases with the increasing distance d between the bulb and board surfaces. Tests 5 and 6 lasted for more than 3 h, but no ignition was observed. The distance beyond which no ignition is observed no matter how long the sample is exposed to the heat source is defined as the critical distance and is denoted by Dcr. According to the results presented in Table 3, the critical distance is somewhere between 0.040 and 0.041 m.

sec.title: Derivation of the theoretical models
sec.p: The ignition of the timber board in the current study can be characterized as the ignition of a thermally thick material.5 The ignition of wood has been a classic topic in the literature of fire science. It has been established that for solid fuel, there is a critical surface temperature beyond which the nonpiloted ignition will occur.6 Corresponding to this, critical surface temperature is the minimum heat flux below which no ignition will occur, no matter how long the fuel is exposed to the heat source.2

For the ignition problem investigated in the current study, the heat source is the incandescent element of the light bulb, and the heat flux generated by the element is a function of the distance from the element. The theoretical analysis in the current study aims to establish a correlation between the power of a given incandescent light bulb and the critical distance at and below which the ignition of the Paulownia timber board will occur. In the analysis, the heat transfer process is treated as a one-dimensional case.

sec.title: Modeling ignition of wood
sec.p: The ignition process of solid fuel is essentially a heat and mass transfer process.2,7,8 Subjected to external radiant heating, the heated area of wood surface starts to decompose when a certain temperature is attained, and the pyrolysis volatile emanates from the solid combustible and mixes with fresh air. Once the concentration and the temperature of combustible mixed gas are sufficient, the radiant ignition is triggered.

The incandescent core of the light bulb emits thermal radiation in all directions, and the heat flux received by the timber board is nonparallel and nonuniform as shown in Figure 6(a). The heat transfer process in the wood is essentially a three-dimensional one. However, since wood is a poor heat conductor and the ignition usually occurs in a very narrow region over which the radiant heat flux has minimal variation, it will be plausible to simplify the problem into one dimension with uniform heat flux as shown in Figure 6(b). The well-established one-dimensional ignition theory can then be applied. By superadding the heat of gasification loss at the surface of the timber, the complete heat transfer progress is shown in Figure 6(b).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The critical ignition distance from the 200 W incandescent light bulb to the Paulownia wood was estimated to be 6.4 mm according to the ignition model. On the other hand, the ignition simulation experiment revealed that the critical distance is somewhere between 5 and 6 mm. The difference between the modeling and the experimental results may be due to the neglecting of heat conduction and pyrolysis terms in the estimate of minimum heat flux in the model.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: It has been demonstrated experimentally in this study that ignition of a particular timber species by an incandescent light bulb is possible. The experimental results revealed that for a given power output of the light, it is relatively easier to ignite a horizontal timber board when the light bulb is placed beneath it than in the cases where the bulb is placed above the board or the board is in the vertical orientation. For the horizontal board and bulb beneath configuration, the time to ignition is proportional to the separation distance between the bulb and the board, and there is a critical distance beyond which the ignition will not occur. A simple model based on the minimum heat flux concept was established to correlate the ignition time with the separate distance for this particular orientation. The results using the model agreed with that of the experiments reasonably well.

It should be pointed that the minimum heat flux is a configuration-dependent as well as fuel material property–dependent parameter. Different values of minimum heat flux may exist for even the same material at different orientations. The estimation of the minimum heat flux in this study was based on the ignition temperature of wood. For the board horizontal and bulb beneath configuration, the estimated critical distance agrees well with the experimental result.

Comparing Tests 1–6 with Tests 7 and 8 shows that the minimum heat flux for vertical board is larger than placed horizontally, and vertical board is much more difficult to be ignited. In the case of the timber board placed horizontally above the light bulb, it can be ignited if the distance from the incandescent light bulb core to timber board surface is less than 7 mm.

This study confirmed that the incandescent light bulb used at the construction site is a likely ignition source of the fire that occurred on 16 March 2004 in Korla City, Sinkiang Autonomy Region of China. It can also be asserted that the piece of timber was much more difficult to be ignited by the incandescent light in the vertical orientation. In this study, the ignition time and critical distance to ignition was correlated based on a simple model. The conduction and gasification terms in the formula used to estimate the minimum heat flux need to be considered, and more board orientations in the experiment need to be conducted to solve the limitation.
